TextEquiv.Unicode: SAN DIEGO SOCIETY OF NATURAL HISTORY

This strongly concentrically sculptured little species can be immediately recognized by its long, attenuated rostrum (posterior extension), which is squarely truncated at the end. The posterior, gently curved dorsal margin is much longer than the anterior.

A number of species of “Leda” have been described from the earlier Tertiary of the Paciﬁc coast. Some of the Miocene ones are noted here, as they may be closely related to Pliocene species. “Yoldia” newcombi Anderson and Martin,1 from the “Lower Miocene of Clallam County, Washington,” is a Nuculana of the typical section, somewhat resem- bling N. conceptionis Dall, but is more attenuated. “Leda” ochsneri of the same authors, from the lower Miocene of Kern River, Kern County, California, is closely related to N. taphria, as suggested in the original description. “Leda” cahillensis Arnold2 likewise belongs to Sacella. “Leda” chehalisensis Weaver3 from the Chehalis formation of western Washington, and “Leda” furlongi Trask,4 of the Briones formation of California, appear to be closely related; they probably belong likewise to Sacella Woodring. “Leda” wil- lamettensis Shumard, from the Miocene of the Willamette Valley, Oregon, has not been ﬁgured, but as it is an early described species and might be recognized from topotype ma- terial, Shumard's description is reproduced below in full.
Leda willamettensis Shumard, Trans Acad. of Sci. of St. Louis, Vol. 1, p. 121, 1858, no ﬁgure; Dall, U. S. Geol. Surv., Prof. Paper 59, p. 104, 1909.

“Shell small, oblong-ovate, convex, inequilateral; buccal margin gently arched, and forming with the cardinal margin nearly a right angle; anal side prolonged, rostrated, truncated at the extremity; basal margin slightly arched; cardinal border oblique in advance of the beak and slightly excavated behind; beaks sub-medial not very prominent. The surface markings are entirely obliterated on the only specimen we have obtained of this species.
“Form. & Loc.—Occurs with Lucina parilis in dark-gray silicious limestone at Brooks' Lime Quarry, Willamette Valley, ﬁve miles north of Salem, Oregon Territory.” (Shumard, 1858.)
Shumard gave no measurements nor ﬁgures, and according to Dall the type is lost.

Yoldia H. P. C. Möller, Index Molluscorum Groenlandiæ, p. 18, 1842; Stoliczka, Mem. Geol. Surv. India, Palaeonto- logia Indica, Vol. 3, p. 320, 1871; Meek, U. S. Geol. Surv. Territories, Vol. 9, p. 107, 1876; Verrill and Bush, Amer. Jour. Sci., Ser. 4, Vol. 3, p. 55, 1897; Dall, Trans. Wagner Inst. Sci., Vol. 3, pp. 594, 595, 1898; Woodring, Carnegie Inst. Publ., No. 366, p. 21, 1925.
Type (see below): Nucula arctica Gray, Supplement to the Appendix Parry's First Voyage, 1819-20, p. 241, 1824; circumboreal; ﬁgured herewith, plate 1, ﬁgures 10, 11.

Yoldia and Nuculana are closely related, but Yoldia can generally be diﬀerentiated by its strong keel on the posterior dorsal margin, by its gape at both ends, and by the somewhat thinner shell. Sacella Woodring is quite diﬀerent from Yoldia, s. s., but Nuculana, s. s., is a close approach to the Yoldia myalis Couthouy group. Yoldia has
1 Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., Ser. 4, Vol. 4, p. 54, pl. 3, ﬁg. 2, 1914.
2 Proc. U. S. Nat. Mus., Vol. 34, p. 375, pl. 34, ﬁg. 9, 1908, lower Miocene of Santa Cruz Quadrangle, Calif.
3 Washington Geol. Surv., Bull. 15, p. 56, pl. 12, ﬁgs. 104, 105, 1912.
4 Univ. Calif. Publ. Geol., Vol. 13, p. 147, pl. 1, ﬁgs. 1a-b, 1922.
